awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Desalination Batteries for Energy-Efficient Desalination and Selective Chloride Removal
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is in comprehensively addressing issues related to water treatment, environment protection, and resource recovery through the development of a new desalination technology called a desalination battery. Steady growth in human population and rapid industrial development have led to greater demands for clean water production. At the same time, anthropogenic activities, agricultural practices, and the disposal of wastewater have led to the salinization of natural freshwater resources. The desalination battery combines the functions of desalination and energy generation to reduce the energy and costs associated with desalination, addressing challenges at the intersection of the water-energy nexus. The goal of the proposed research is to accelerate the commercialization of the desalination battery by evaluating the effects of various solution components present in real feedwater types on performance. The project will also establish mitigation plans for problematic solution components. Successful development of the desalination battery will help to safeguard access to freshwater resources and ensure an adequate water supply, which are essential to advance the health and welfare of the American public. Commercialization of the proposed technology will also create jobs for researchers and engineers making a positive economic impact.  

The goal of this STTR project is to further develop a new desalination technology, a desalination battery, which is based on the patented use of bismuth (Bi) as a chloride (Cl)-storage electrode in combination with a sodium (Na)-storage electrode. The desalination battery stores and releases energy during the charging and discharging processes. These processes are coupled with the storage and release of Na+ and Cl-. As the energy consumed during charging is recovered during discharging, the net energy required for desalination is drastically reduced. Furthermore, since Na+ and Cl- are removed via ion-specific electrode reactions, it enables membrane-free desalination. While efficient removal of NaCl has been demonstrated, the effects of various other solution components present in real wastewater and seawater are still unknown. The goal of the proposed work is to accurately evaluate the effects of different salinities, pH conditions, and various inorganic and organic species present in real feedwater on the performance of the desalination battery. The project will also develop mitigation plans for any problematic solution components. Accurate technoeconomic calculations will be used to prioritize the most promising feedwater targets and to develop a tailored commercialization plan for specific applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The data is staggering; over 800 million people currently experience water scarcity and water demand is continuing to increase. At the same time, pervasive drought conditions, anthropogenic activities (e.g., road salt), agricultural practices, and the disposal of wastewater effluent have led to salinization of natural freshwater resources. Dissolved salt contains Clˉ, which is harmful to freshwater aquatic species, threatens the availability of drinking water, and is notoriously difficult to remove from water. To manage concerns about increasing Clˉ concentrations, regulators have imposed Clˉ limits for municipal and industrial wastewater dischargers. As the long-term consequences of Clˉ discharge have become better understood, regulations have also gotten stricter. The treatment technologies currently available for Clˉ removal are reverse osmosis (RO), electrodialysis (ED), and thermal evaporation. All three processes were designed to remove all ions from water, not just Clˉ. Non-selective ion removal increases the cost and makes these processes ill-suited to Clˉ removal from wastewater. RO and ED also produce a concentrated brine waste product that is difficult and expensive to dispose of and causes additional environmental consequences. Thus, there is currently no effective way to enforce Clˉ regulations without imposing a serious financial burden on wastewater facilities and industry. ChloBis Water is the developer of a Cl-selective removal/recovery technology that addresses the challenges of conventional desalination methods. This technology relies on the patented use of Bismuth (Bi) as a Cl-selective storage electrode to remove only Clˉ from wastewater to comply with effluent limits. The selectively removed Clˉ is then directly recovered as a useful commodity chemical, such as HOCl (used for wastewater disinfection and cleaning), creating a closed loop Cl-removal and recovery cycle.

Intellectual Merit: Prior to the Phase I STTR project, electrodes had only been tested in high-purity 0.6 M NaCl solutions (mimicking the salinity of seawater) and we did not know how the electrodes would perform in other salinities and pH conditions and in the presence of other inorganic ions and organic matter sources. When the Phase I project began, we were considering treatment of four feedwater types (municipal wastewater, industrial wastewater, seawater, highly concentrated brine solutions). With support from the Phase I STTR program, we have narrowed our focus to Clˉ selective removal and recovery from two water types: municipal wastewater and industrial wastewater because

  • Our system can only be used to remove Na+ and Clˉ from water and freshwater production from seawater requires the removal of other ions. Thus, our technology cannot be used as a standalone system for seawater desalination but can be used as a standalone system for wastewater treatment.
  • We can implement a smaller scale device (the amount of Clˉ that needs to be removed for wastewater treatment is lower than that for seawater desalination). Deployment of a smaller scale device will serve to de-risk our product commercialization pathway with minimal capital investment and will provide an early source of revenue to support the development of a seawater desalination system in the future.
  • For Cl-specific removal, the Cl-storage electrode can be paired with a readily available off-the-shelf electrode that performs other counter electrode reactions (water reduction/HOCl production). By focusing first on the development of the Bi electrode, the time and capital required for product commercialization will be cut in half.
  • Market research and customer discovery have revealed that stricter Clˉ regulations are on the horizon. Our development timeline and expected regulatory changes are in alignment and we have a unique opportunity to capitalize on impending regulatory pressure as the only Clˉ selective, brine free system on the market. 

Broader Impacts: This Cl-specific removal/recovery technology has the potential to comprehensively address issues related to water treatment, environment protection, and resource recovery, and commercialization of this technology will undoubtedly have a clear societal impact. This technology provides an affordable solution for Clˉ removal, which will in turn enable state and federal agencies to enforce Clˉ regulations to protect freshwater resources without hurting the prosperity of industry. ChloBis Water?s development timeline and expected regulatory changes are in alignment and ChloBis Water has a unique opportunity to capitalize on impending regulatory pressure as the only Clˉ selective, brine free system on the market. We plan to expand to the seawater desalination market in the future. Finally, two of ChloBis Water?s co-founders are women and ChloBis Water is led by a female CEO. They will contribute to bridging the gender gap in leadership roles at startups and will serve as positive role models to encourage more female graduate students, PIs, and postdoctoral scholars to pursue opportunities in technology entrepreneurship.
